query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Solea creder lo mondo in suo periclo 2 che la bella Ciprigna il folle amore 3 raggiasse, volta nel terzo epiciclo;

Please translate each line literally into English.
4 per che non pur a lei faceano onore 5 di sacrificio e di votivo grido 6 le genti antiche ne l’antico errore;

Please translate each line literally into English.
7 ma Dïone onoravano e Cupido, 8 quella per madre sua, questo per figlio, 9 e dicean ch’el sedette in grembo a Dido;
query.result:
7 but they also honored Dione and Cupid, 8 she as his mother, he as her son, 9 and they said that he sat in Dido's lap;
(Note: The word "Dïone" is an alternative name for Venus, the Roman goddess of love and beauty.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 e da costei ond’ io principio piglio 11 pigliavano il vocabol de la stella 12 che ’l sol vagheggia or da coppa or da ciglio.
query.result:
10 and from her from whom I take my beginning, 11 they took the name of the star 12 that the sun courts, sometimes from above, sometimes from below.
(Note: The "her" in line 10 refers to Venus, the goddess of love and beauty. The "star" in line 12 is the planet Venus, which is often called the "morning star" or "evening star" because it can be seen in the sky either before sunrise or after sunset.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Io non m’accorsi del salire in ella; 14 ma d’esservi entro mi fé assai fede 15 la donna mia ch’i’ vidi far più bella.

Please translate each line literally into English.
16 E come in fiamma favilla si vede, 17 e come in voce voce si discerne, 18 quand’ una è ferma e altra va e riede,
query.result: 16 And as a spark is seen in a flame, 17 and as a voice is discerned in a voice, 18 when one is steady and the other goes and returns,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 vid’ io in essa luce altre lucerne 20 muoversi in giro più e men correnti, 21 al modo, credo, di lor viste interne.
query.result: 19 so in that light I saw other lights 20 moving in a circle, faster and slower, 21 according to, I believe, their internal visions.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Di fredda nube non disceser venti, 23 o visibili o no, tanto festini, 24 che non paressero impediti e lenti
query.result: 22 No winds descended from a cold cloud, 23 whether visible or not, so swift, 24 that they would not have seemed impeded and slow

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 a chi avesse quei lumi divini 26 veduti a noi venir, lasciando il giro 27 pria cominciato in li alti Serafini;

Please translate each line literally into English.
28 e dentro a quei che più innanzi appariro 29 sonava ‘Osanna’ sì, che unque poi 30 di rïudir non fui sanza disiro.
query.result: 28 and within those that appeared in front 29 resounded ‘Hosanna’ so that never after 30 was I without the desire to hear it again.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Indi si fece l’un più presso a noi 32 e solo incominciò: «Tutti sem presti 33 al tuo piacer, perché di noi ti gioi.
query.result: 31 Then one of them drew nearer to us 32 and began, speaking for all: “We are all ready 33 to do your bidding, because you take joy in us.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Noi ci volgiam coi principi celesti 35 d’un giro e d’un girare e d’una sete, 36 ai quali tu del mondo già dicesti:
query.result: 34 We revolve with the celestial principalities 35 in one gyre, one revolution, and one desire, 36 to whom you once said of the world:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 ‘Voi che ’ntendendo il terzo ciel movete’; 38 e sem sì pien d’amor, che, per piacerti, 39 non fia men dolce un poco di quïete».

Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Poscia che li occhi miei si fuoro offerti 41 a la mia donna reverenti, ed essa 42 fatti li avea di sé contenti e certi,
query.result: 40 After my eyes had offered themselves 41 reverently to my lady, and she 42 had made them content and certain of her,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 rivolsersi a la luce che promessa 44 tanto s’avea, e «Deh, chi siete?» fue 45 la voce mia di grande affetto impressa.
query.result: 43 they turned to the light that had promised 44 so much of itself, and “Ah, who are you?” was 45 my voice, marked by great affection.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 E quanta e quale vid’ io lei far piùe 47 per allegrezza nova che s’accrebbe, 48 quando parlai, a l’allegrezze sue!
query.result: 46 And how much and how greatly did I see her grow 47 in new joy that increased, 48 when I spoke, her own joy!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Così fatta, mi disse: «Il mondo m’ebbe 50 giù poco tempo; e se più fosse stato, 51 molto sarà di mal, che non sarebbe.
query.result: 49 Thus transformed, she said to me: “The world had me 50 for a short time; and if I had stayed longer, 51 there would be much evil that would not be.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 La mia letizia mi ti tien celato 53 che mi raggia dintorno e mi nasconde 54 quasi animal di sua seta fasciato.
query.result: 52 My joy keeps me hidden from you, 53 which radiates around me and conceals me, 54 like an animal wrapped in its silk.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Assai m’amasti, e avesti ben onde; 56 che s’io fossi giù stato, io ti mostrava 57 di mio amor più oltre che le fronde.

Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Quella sinistra riva che si lava 59 di Rodano poi ch’è misto con Sorga, 60 per suo segnore a tempo m’aspettava,
query.result: 58 That left bank which is washed 59 by the Rhone after it has mingled with the Sorgue, 60 awaited me as its lord for a time,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 e quel corno d’Ausonia che s’imborga 62 di Bari e di Gaeta e di Catona, 63 da ove Tronto e Verde in mare sgorga.
query.result: 61 and that horn of Ausonia which is bounded 62 by Bari, Gaeta, and Catona, 63 from where the Tronto and Verde flow into the sea.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Fulgeami già in fronte la corona 65 di quella terra che ’l Danubio riga 66 poi che le ripe tedesche abbandona.
query.result: 64 The crown of that land which the Danube irrigates 65 was already gleaming on my brow, 66 after it leaves the German banks.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
67 E la bella Trinacria, che caliga 68 tra Pachino e Peloro, sopra ’l golfo 69 che riceve da Euro maggior briga,
query.result: 67 And beautiful Trinacria, which lies shrouded in mist 68 between Pachino and Pelorus, above the gulf 69 that receives the greatest force from the east wind,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 non per Tifeo ma per nascente solfo, 71 attesi avrebbe li suoi regi ancora, 72 nati per me di Carlo e di Ridolfo,
query.result: 70 not because of Typhon but because of the sulfur that is born there, 71 would still be awaiting its kings, 72 born for me from Charles and Rudolph,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 se mala segnoria, che sempre accora 74 li popoli suggetti, non avesse 75 mosso Palermo a gridar: “Mora, mora!”.
query.result: 73 if bad governance, which always grieves 74 the subject peoples, had not 75 stirred up Palermo to cry out: “Death, death!”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 E se mio frate questo antivedesse, 77 l’avara povertà di Catalogna 78 già fuggeria, perché non li offendesse;

Please translate each line literally into English.
79 ché veramente proveder bisogna 80 per lui, o per altrui, sì ch’a sua barca 81 carcata più d’incarco non si pogna.
query.result: 79 for truly it is necessary to provide 80 for him, or for someone else, so that his bark 81 is not burdened with more cargo than it can carry.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 La sua natura, che di larga parca 83 discese, avria mestier di tal milizia 84 che non curasse di mettere in arca».
query.result: 82 His nature, which descended from a generous parsimoniousness, 83 would have need of such a militia 84 that would not care to put money in the coffers.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 «Però ch’i’ credo che l’alta letizia 86 che ’l tuo parlar m’infonde, segnor mio, 87 là ’ve ogne ben si termina e s’inizia,
query.result: 85 “Because I believe that the supreme joy 86 that your speech infuses in me, my lord, 87 there where every good thing ends and begins,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
88 per te si veggia come la vegg’ io, 89 grata m’è più; e anco quest’ ho caro 90 perché ’l discerni rimirando in Dio.
query.result: 88 is seen by you as I see it, 89 it is more pleasing to me; and this too I hold dear 90 because you discern it by gazing upon God.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Fatto m’hai lieto, e così mi fa chiaro, 92 poi che, parlando, a dubitar m’hai mosso 93 com’ esser può, di dolce seme, amaro».
query.result: 91 You have made me glad, and you also make it clear to me, 92 since, by speaking, you have moved me to question 93 how it is possible for a sweet seed to produce bitter fruit.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Questo io a lui; ed elli a me: «S’io posso 95 mostrarti un vero, a quel che tu dimandi 96 terrai lo viso come tien lo dosso.
query.result: 94 This I said to him; and he to me: “If I can 95 show you a truth, you will hold your gaze fixed on that 96 which you are asking about, as the back holds itself erect.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Lo ben che tutto il regno che tu scandi 98 volge e contenta, fa esser virtute 99 sua provedenza in questi corpi grandi.
query.result: 97 The good which revolves and satisfies the entire kingdom 98 that you are ascending makes its providence to be virtue 99 in these great bodies.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 E non pur le nature provedute 101 sono in la mente ch’è da sé perfetta, 102 ma esse insieme con la lor salute:
query.result: 100 And not only are the natures provided for 101 in the mind that is perfect in itself, 102 but they together with their salvation:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 per che quantunque quest’ arco saetta 104 disposto cade a proveduto fine, 105 sì come cosa in suo segno diretta.
query.result: 103 for however this bow shoots, 104 it falls in a way that is disposed toward a providential end, 105 just like something directed at its target.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Se ciò non fosse, il ciel che tu cammine 107 producerebbe sì li suoi effetti, 108 che non sarebbero arti, ma ruine;

Please translate each line literally into English.
109 e ciò esser non può, se li ’ntelletti 110 che muovon queste stelle non son manchi, 111 e manco il primo, che non li ha perfetti.
query.result: 109 and this cannot be, if the intelligences 110 that move these stars are not deficient, 111 and least of all the first, which has not made them perfect.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Vuo’ tu che questo ver più ti s’imbianchi?». 113 E io: «Non già; ché impossibil veggio 114 che la natura, in quel ch’è uopo, stanchi».
query.result: 112 “Do you want this truth to become even clearer to you?” 113 And I: “Not at all; for I see it is impossible 114 that nature, in what is necessary, should fail.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 Ond’ elli ancora: «Or dì: sarebbe il peggio 116 per l’omo in terra, se non fosse cive?». 117 «Sì», rispuos’ io; «e qui ragion non cheggio».
query.result: 115 Then he continued: “Now tell me: would it be the worst thing 116 for man on earth, if he were not a citizen?” 117 “Yes,” I replied; “and I do not ask for any reasoning here.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 «E puot’ elli esser, se giù non si vive 119 diversamente per diversi offici? 120 Non, se ’l maestro vostro ben vi scrive».
query.result: 118 “And can he be, if down below 119 people do not live differently according to different duties? 120 Not, if your master writes to you correctly.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Sì venne deducendo infino a quici; 122 poscia conchiuse: «Dunque esser diverse 123 convien di vostri effetti le radici:

Please translate each line literally into English.
124 per ch’un nasce Solone e altro Serse, 125 altro Melchisedèch e altro quello 126 che, volando per l’aere, il figlio perse.
query.result: 124 for one is born a Solon and another a Xerxes, 125 another a Melchizedek and another the one 126 who, flying through the air, lost his son.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 La circular natura, ch’è suggello 128 a la cera mortal, fa ben sua arte, 129 ma non distingue l’un da l’altro ostello.
query.result: 127 The circular nature, which is the seal 128 on the mortal wax, does its work well, 129 but it does not distinguish one dwelling from another.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Quinci addivien ch’Esaù si diparte 131 per seme da Iacòb; e vien Quirino 132 da sì vil padre, che si rende a Marte.
query.result: 130 Hence it happens that Esau is separated 131 by seed from Jacob; and Quirinus comes 132 from a father so vile that he surrenders to Mars.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Natura generata il suo cammino 134 simil farebbe sempre a’ generanti, 135 se non vincesse il proveder divino.
query.result: 133 Generated nature would always make its course 134 similar to its progenitors, 135 if divine providence did not prevail.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 Or quel che t’era dietro t’è davanti: 137 ma perché sappi che di te mi giova, 138 un corollario voglio che t’ammanti.
query.result: 136 Now what was behind you is before you: 137 but so that you may know that I take pleasure in you, 138 I want you to adorn yourself with a corollary.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Sempre natura, se fortuna trova 140 discorde a sé, com’ ogne altra semente 141 fuor di sua regïon, fa mala prova.
query.result: 139 Whenever nature finds 140 fortune discordant with itself, like any other seed 141 outside its own region, it makes a poor showing.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
142 E se ’l mondo là giù ponesse mente 143 al fondamento che natura pone, 144 seguendo lui, avria buona la gente.
query.result: 142 And if the world down there would pay attention 143 to the foundation that nature lays, 144 following it, people would be good.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
145 Ma voi torcete a la religïone 146 tal che fia nato a cignersi la spada, 147 e fate re di tal ch’è da sermone;

148 onde la traccia vostra è fuor di strada».
query.result: 148 so your path is astray.”
